metadata.unitName: TEST orange Forces Shape Earth's Surface

questions.question: Which list shows the layers of Earth in order from the outside moving toward the centre?

answers.content: Crust → Mantle → Outer core → Inner core
answers.explanation: Earth’s outermost rocky crust surrounds the semi-solid mantle, which encloses the liquid outer core and solid inner core.

answers.content: Mantle → Crust → Inner core → Outer core
Crust → Outer core → Mantle → Inner core
Inner core → Outer core → Mantle → Crust

questions.question: Why is the inner core solid even though it is about as hot as the surface of the Sun?

answers.content: The intense pressure at Earth’s centre keeps the iron–nickel alloy locked in a solid state.
answers.explanation: Enormous pressure outweighs the high temperature, preventing the inner core from melting.

answers.content: There is no metal in the inner core so it cannot melt.
The inner core is made of frozen water ice.
Heat cannot reach the centre of Earth.

questions.question: Which Earth layer is responsible for the slow convection currents that help move tectonic plates?

answers.explanation: Semi-solid, viscous rock in the mantle circulates slowly, driving plate motion.

questions.question: The outer core is mostly composed of which two metals?

answers.explanation: Both the outer and inner core are rich in iron and nickel.

questions.question: Describe two differences between Earth’s crust and mantle. Write in complete sentences using Tier 2 or Tier 3 vocabulary.

answers.content: Sample answer: The crust is a thin, rigid shell made of solid rock, averaging about 30 km thick under continents, whereas the mantle is around 2 900 km thick and consists of hot, semi-molten rock that can flow slowly by convection.
answers.explanation: Award 1 mark for identifying a difference in thickness, 1 mark for describing a difference in composition/state, and 1 mark for using appropriate scientific vocabulary (e.g., rigid, semi-molten, convection).

questions.question: Draw a cross-section of Earth showing the crust, mantle, outer core and inner core. Label each layer and annotate your diagram with one fact about temperature or thickness for every layer.

answers.content: Rubric: 1 mark for accurate outline and inclusion of all four layers; 1 mark for correct labels; 2 marks for relevant, accurate annotations (½ mark each, maximum 2).

questions.question: What is the primary cause of an earthquake?

answers.content: The gradual cooling of Earth’s core
answers.explanation: Cooling of the core does not generate sudden shaking at Earth’s surface.

answers.content: Sudden release of energy when tectonic plates get stuck and then slip past each other
answers.explanation: Stress builds along plate boundaries until it is suddenly released, producing seismic waves.
Erosion is a gradual surface process, not a sudden ground-shaking event.

answers.content: Daily tides caused by the Moon
answers.explanation: Tides move water, not Earth’s crust.

questions.question: In the Mars-bar model, what does the cracked chocolate layer represent?

answers.explanation: The mantle lies beneath the crust in the model (the caramel/nougat).
The rigid chocolate coating models the brittle crust that breaks during an earthquake.
Water is not represented in the chocolate bar model.
The atmosphere surrounds Earth and is not modelled by the bar.

questions.question: Name ONE specific change to the landscape caused by the 2024 Noto Peninsula earthquake.

answers.content: The coastline was lifted up, creating new dry land where sea once was.

questions.question: In the sentence, "The earthquake struck, so the land rose up," the word "so" is functioning as a:

answers.explanation: Temporal connectives relate to time sequence, not cause.
"So" links the cause (earthquake) with its effect (land rose up).
Contrast connectives include words like "but" or "however."
Adverbs of place indicate location.

questions.question:
Complete the cause-and-effect statement using a causal connective:
"The earthquake struck ____________ the roads split apart and deep cracks opened."

Draw and label a diagram that models how pushing two halves of a chocolate bar together represents tectonic plates converging to cause an earthquake. Include labels for: Plate A, Plate B, cracked crust, and direction of movement.

answers.content: Student provides a clear, labelled diagram showing two blocks moving toward each other, cracked chocolate indicating the crust buckling.

questions.question: What is the molten rock that is stored beneath Earth’s surface called?

answers.explanation: Lava is the name given to molten rock that has reached the surface.
Molten rock is called magma while it is still beneath Earth’s crust.
Ash is made of tiny rock fragments ejected during an eruption.
Pumice is a volcanic rock that forms after an eruption.

questions.question: Name one constructive effect that a volcanic eruption can have on the landscape.

answers.explanation: Lava flows can cool and harden to form brand-new land masses.
Volcanic ash breaks down to create mineral-rich soils ideal for growing plants.

questions.question: In the classroom model, which two common ingredients are mixed to simulate a volcanic eruption?

answers.explanation: The reaction between baking soda and vinegar produces gas that mimics an eruption.

questions.question:
Complete the sentence using a causal connective: 
“Because volcanic ash is rich in minerals, ______________________________.”

answers.content: it makes the surrounding soil very fertile
answers.explanation: Mineral-rich ash eventually weathers into fertile soil that supports plant life.

questions.question: Most volcanoes form at which location on Earth?

answers.content: Along the edges where tectonic plates meet
answers.explanation: Plate boundaries provide pathways for magma to reach the surface.

questions.question: Which immediate landscape change from an eruption could have the knock-on effect of providing “more space for people and animals to live”?

answers.explanation: Cooling lava can add land area, which later becomes available for habitation.

questions.question: Which term describes the process that breaks rocks into smaller pieces without moving them to a new place?

answers.explanation: Weathering breaks rocks down in the same place.
Erosion moves the broken pieces elsewhere.
Deposition is when eroded material is dropped in a new location.
Melting changes a solid to a liquid, not the surface of rocks.

questions.question: Which of the following was NOT identified as an agent of weathering in this lesson?

answers.explanation: Wind was explored as an agent that blasts sand against rocks.
Rivers, rain and waves were discussed as weathering forces.
Growing roots can split rocks apart.
Lightning was not covered as a common agent of weathering in this lesson.

questions.question: In one or two sentences, explain how moving water can cause rocks to weather.

answers.content: Flowing rivers, ocean waves and rain carry sand and other particles that repeatedly scrape against rock surfaces, gradually wearing them down and making them smoother and smaller.

questions.question: What is the key difference between weathering and erosion?

answers.content: Weathering moves broken rock; erosion only breaks it down.
answers.explanation: This reverses the definitions.

answers.content: Weathering breaks rock apart; erosion transports the broken pieces.
answers.explanation: Weathering and erosion often work together but are distinct processes.

answers.content: Weathering happens quickly; erosion is always slow.
answers.explanation: Both processes can be slow or, in rare cases, rapid.

answers.content: Erosion only occurs under water; weathering only occurs on land.
answers.explanation: Both can occur in many environments.

questions.question: Draw and label a simple flow chart that shows the steps of how wind weathers rocks and eventually changes the landscape. Include at least three labelled steps.

answers.content: Expected drawing shows: 1) Wind picks up sand and small particles; 2) Particles blast against rock surfaces chipping tiny fragments; 3) Over time sharp edges become rounded and rock forms change.
answers.explanation: Marks awarded for including three logical, labelled steps demonstrating understanding of wind-driven abrasion.

questions.question: What is erosion?

answers.content: The breaking of rocks into smaller pieces on Earth’s surface.
answers.explanation: This describes weathering, not erosion.

answers.content: The movement of rocks, soil and sand from one place to another.
answers.explanation: Erosion is defined as the transport of weathered material.

answers.content: The settling of rock fragments in a new location.
answers.explanation: This is deposition, not erosion.

answers.content: The cooling of molten rock below Earth’s surface.
answers.explanation: This describes igneous rock formation, not erosion.

questions.question: In the class investigation, which tray demonstrated the greatest amount of erosion?

answers.explanation: Water flowed slowly on the flat surface, producing little erosion.
Some erosion occurred, but not the most.
The steeper slope increased water speed and force, causing the most erosion.
Different slopes produced different erosion levels.

questions.question: Explain why water flowing down a steeper slope causes more erosion than water flowing down a gentle slope.

answers.content: A steeper slope makes the water move faster, increasing its kinetic energy and force. The faster-moving water can pick up and carry more sand, soil and small rocks, so more material is removed from the slope and transported elsewhere.

questions.question: During the fair-test investigation, what was the independent variable (the one thing you changed)?

answers.content: The amount of water poured into each tray
answers.explanation: The same amount of water was used in each trial.

answers.content: The slope angle of the tray
answers.explanation: Only the slope angle (flat, gentle, steep) was changed.
The same sand was used in every tray.

answers.content: The length of the river drawn in the sand
answers.explanation: The river length was kept the same.

questions.question: Which statement best describes deposition?

answers.content: Wind blows sand off a beach and drops it on nearby dunes.
answers.explanation: The sand is moved (erosion) and then dropped (deposition) on the dunes.

answers.content: Rainwater breaks a rock into smaller pieces.
answers.explanation: This is weathering.

answers.content: River water dissolves minerals from a rock face.
answers.explanation: This is chemical weathering.

answers.content: Waves crash against a cliff, knocking loose pebbles into the water.
answers.explanation: This is erosion, not deposition.

questions.question: Aboriginal Dreaming stories, such as ‘Super Snake’, explain the creation of landforms primarily through:

answers.content: The action of natural forces like wind and water
answers.explanation: Scientific perspective, not Dreaming stories.

answers.content: The activities of ancestral beings and spirits
answers.explanation: Dreaming stories attribute landscape formation to ancestral beings.
Modern geological explanation, not the Dreaming view.

answers.content: Human engineering over thousands of years
answers.explanation: Not referenced in Dreaming stories.

questions.question: Name two natural forces other than flowing water that can cause erosion.

answers.content: Wind and ice (glaciers) are two other natural forces that can erode Earth’s surface. Gravity-driven mass movement is another acceptable answer.

questions.question: On a separate sheet or digital canvas, draw and label the three trays from the investigation. Show the path of the water and the amount of sand that collected at the bottom of each tray.

answers.content:
Drawing clearly shows:
• Tray 1 flat: little sand moved (1 mark)
• Tray 2 gentle slope: moderate sand deposited (1 mark)
• Tray 3 steep slope: large amount of sand deposited (1 mark)
• Labels/annotations describing water speed and erosion (1 mark)
answers.explanation: Use this rubric to award marks for the drawing.
